text:
High Bridge Park: An old house between High and Washington Bridges. In the background appears the apartment ridges of the Bronx on the far side of the Harlem River. This is a set of two views; No. 1 being in a southward direction and showing the structure that carries the water tubes to Manhattan. No. 2 is in the opposite direction and shows the vehicular bond.

April 8, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: High Bridge Park.

folder: High Bridge Park & [Amsterdam Avenue.], Manhattan, NY
text:
(1)
Highbridge Park: The pump house, set in a hollow between High Bridge and Washington Bridge. The latter appears partially on the right; photographers view being northward.

April 8, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, in the same direction and showing the general area. Buildings appearing on the left, line the western boundary of the Park, which at this point is Amsterdam Ave.

April 8, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: High Bridge Park - [Amsterdam Avenue.]

folder: High Bridge Park & [173rd Street & 181st Street (West).], Manhattan, NY
text:
Highbridge Park: A view northward of the southern extremity of this rocky area that parallels the Harlem River. The western boundary of same is Edgecombe Ave., which appears on the left. The water tower, reservoir and High Bridge are in the center of this elongated rocky slope, at the foot of West 173rd Street. North of the latter point and at the foot of West 181st Street is the Washington Bridge. These structures connect Manhattan with the Washington Heights section of the Bronx. This is a set of three views, more or less similar.

April 8, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: High Bridge Park - [173rd Street - 181st Street (West).]

folder: St. Nicholas Avenue & Fairmont Avenue, Manhattan, NY
original_title: Manhattan: St. Nicholas Avenue - Fairmont Avenue
text:
(1)
St. Nicholas Avenue, (Formerly Eleventh Avenue), north from Fairview Avenue. At this point the Avenue winds down the hill from Fort George, coming to an end at Dyckman Street and Nagle Avenue, Inwood. The apartment buildings shown to the right are rather new.
October 6, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, at a later date. From this point of vantage is seen a magnificent panoramic view of the northernmost sector of Manhattan, north from Dyckman Street extending to Spuyten Duyvil. In the distant background are visible the Palisades of New Jersey. The buildings shown (right foreground) are Nos. 1658-1670 St. Nicholas Ave. (the 2-story building of the Central Shirt Laundry and 672, and 682 Fort George Ave. (the two apartment houses).

April 20, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
The same, from a point slightly northward. Note (centre of view) a portion of the Interborough Rapid Transit subway, running at this point on an elevated structure on Nagle Ave.

P. L. Sperr.

April 20, 1937.

folder: High Bridge Park & [181st Street bridge.], Manhattan, NY
text:
High Bridge Park: The new roadway that links the Harlem River Drive (right) with the George Washington Bridge over the Hudson River. At the left is the distinctive water tower. TPe bridge that identifies this locald is in the center. Beneath same is the vehicular connection with the Bronx. This was formerly the George Vashington Bridge. It is now popularly known as the
181st Street Bridge over the Harlem River.
May 19, 1940
Views 1,2
P. L. Sperr
title: Manhattan: High Bridge Park - [181st Street bridge.]

title: Manhattan: High Bridge Park - [181st Street bridge.]

text:
High Bridge Park: Three views showing mainly the new improvements that have recently been completed. They consist of the distinctive new highway linking the Harlem River Driveway with the Hudson River's George Washington Bridge, and the new swimming pool. Close observation will disclose the latter in the center. Buildings on the left fronts on Amsterdam Avenue. Those on the right are in the Bronx.

June 20, 1940
Views 1,2,3

P. L. Sperr
title: Manhattan: High Bridge Park.
